tossups.question: An author wrote that “if [this character] had not read all those novels...[this character]’s fate might have been different” in The Perpetual Orgy. This character’s eyes are variously described as gray, green, and blue, as pointed out by a Julian Barnes novel. An author allegedly declared “c’est moi”(“say MWAH”) towards this character. This woman throws her bouquet into a fire after a (*) ball. This woman falls ill after being dumped via a letter at the bottom of a barrel of apricots, before becoming indebted to the merchant Lheureux (“luh-ROO”). This resident of Yonville has affairs with Leon and Rodolphe out of boredom with her husband Charles. For 10 points, name this woman who swallows arsenic at the end of a novel by Gustave Flaubert.
tossups.answer: Emma Bovary [accept Madame Bovary; prompt on Bovary] (The Perpetual Orgy is by Mario Vargas Llosa. The Julian Barnes novel is Flaubert’s Parrot.)
tossups.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~27539~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: Thirty years of experiments in this industry are recorded in the journals of 18th-century Yale president Ezra Stiles. John Lombe of Derby (“DAR-bee”) may have been assassinated in 1722 for stealing a “doubler” used in this industry from the Sardinians. Jean-de-Dieu Soult (“ZHAWN duh DYOO soolt”) led an army into Lyon to suppress workers in this industry in the first Canut (“kah-NOO”) Revolt. Equipment needed for this industry was stolen by two (*) Nestorian monks on a mission funded by Justinian the Great. Tash Rabat was one of the caravanserai in Kyrgyzstan that was part of a network named for this industry. This industry was promoted in colonial New England through the importation of mulberry trees. For 10 points, name this industry which also names a “road” to China.
tossups.answer: silk [accept sericulture or silk farming or silkworm industry or silk road; accept the Silk Road; prompt on textiles or clothing industry]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~27426~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: Bonds between these molecules are indicated by parentheses in dot-parentheses notation. Long-range bonds between these molecules form in the wrong order in a pseudoknot and can create a three-way junction in an aptamer. Pi stacking between these molecules stabilizes adjacent rungs of the stem of a hairpin. These heterocyclic molecules are linked by either two or three hydrogen bonds which (*) anneal around 60 degrees Celsius, but melt at 95 in a thermal cycler. A nitrogen atom in these molecules is bonded to the one-prime carbon of deoxyribose. The purine class of these molecules bonds to complementary pyrimidines to hold together the phosphodiester backbone. For 10 points, name these molecules that pair up in DNA.
tossups.answer: DNA bases [or nitrogenous bases; or nucleobases; or nucleotides or nucleosides; accept base pairs; accept purines and pyrimidines until they are read; prompt on adenine or guanine or cytosine or thymine or A or C or G or T by asking “what class of molecules?”; prompt on nucleic acids or DNAs or RNAs or primers or oligonucleotides by asking “which part of the nucleic acid?”]
tossups.metadata: David Bass, Science - Chemistry> ~27415~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: Birgit Nilsson (“BEER-ghit NIL-son”) sang the role of one of these people on three landmark recordings conducted by Georg Solti (“George SHOL-tee”). These characters are represented by a 9/8 (“nine-eight”) brass motif outlining B minor arpeggios and repeatedly cry “Hojotoho!” (“HO-yo-toh-HO”). After her father bids her a tender farewell, one of these people is put to a magic (*) sleep as part of her punishment for disobeying him by helping Siegmund (“ZEEG-munt”) fight Hunding. After becoming mortal, one of these characters dies in her Immolation Scene. One of these daughters of Wotan (“VOH-tahn”) wears a winged helmet and titles the second opera in the Ring Cycle. For 10 points, Brünnhilde (“broon-HILL-duh”) is what type of being who titles an operatic excerpt by Wagner about their “ride”?
tossups.answer: Valkyries [or Walküren; accept shieldmaiden; accept Die Walküre; accept “Ride of the Valkyries” or Walkürenritt or Ritt der Walküren]
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Opera> ~27610~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: During the creation of this substance, the twice-chanted invocation “We beg you to hear us” interrupts the Litany of the Saints on Epiphany’s Eve. Unlike the “greater” blessing that takes place on Theophany, Mary is heavily invoked during this substance’s “lesser” blessing in Orthodox churches. In modern times, an aspergillum (“as-PER-jill-uhm”) delivers this substance instead of a hyssop (“HISS-up”) branch. Exorcized salt is added in a (*) cross pattern when creating this substance, which wards off misfortune when spread during automobile and house blessings. Newly arrived congregants make the sign of the cross with this substance taken from stoups (“stoops”) located at the entrance. For 10 points, babies are immersed in what sacred substance during baptism?
tossups.answer: holy water [or lustral water, or sanctified water, or blessed water, or consecrated water; accept exorcised water until “exorcised” is read, but prompt afterwards; accept baptismal water before “baptism” is read, but prompt afterwards; prompt on water]
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Christian Practice> ~28535~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: Charles Blagden assisted this scientist in measuring the height of Garth Hill with a tripod barometer. This scientist criticized the term “latent heat,” but used it in the manuscript, “Heat,” which, like this scientist’s discovery of Ohm’s law, was published posthumously. This non-French scientist observed the output of a device inherited from John Michell (“me-SHELL”) by using a telescope to read Vernier (“ver-NYAY”) scales through a hole. Cambridge’s Department of Physics is named for this scientist who identified (*) “inflammable air” that was later realized to be pure hydrogen. For 10 points, name this English scientist who used a torsion balance to measure the Earth’s density, indirectly making the first measurement of the gravitational constant.
tossups.answer: Henry Cavendish
tossups.metadata: Joseph Krol, Science - Engineering and Miscellaneous> ~27616~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: A 1982 Philip Glass opera examines how this artist was acquitted for the murder of Harry Larkyns while claiming to be insane after falling off a wagon. Nude women kiss in front of a black tiled wall in a landmark work by this artist. This artist, who changed his name to resemble an Anglo-Saxon King, projected images of athletes onto a rotating glass disc. To best capture Sallie Gardner, this San Franciscan set up a (*) line of cameras. The central characters of Jordan Peele’s film NOPE descend from a Black jockey whom this artist photographed to help Leland Stanford win a bet. For 10 points, name this photographer who invented the zoopraxiscope to record a horse raising its legs off the ground.
tossups.answer: Eadweard Muybridge [or Edward James Muggeridge; or Eduardo Santiago Muybridge; accept Eadweard Muggridge or Eadweard Maybridge; prompt on Helios] (The opera is The Photographer.)
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~27806~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: In 1704, this currency was the first to be decimalized. It’s not the franc, but in 1768, a ruler replaced copper versions of this currency with promissory notes printed by the Assignation Bank. Hard currencies rather than this currency were required to purchase luxury goods in state-run Torgsin stores. A 1998 “crisis” named for this currency followed a fall in the (*) MICEX (“MY-sex”) rate in a country damaged by “shock therapy.” The Comecon used a “convertible” form of this currency, which was produced at a state-owned factory in Goznak. The official exchange rate for this currency against the dollar was amended to be closer to the black-market rate during the era of perestroika. For 10 points, name this Russian currency.
tossups.answer: ruble [or rouble; accept Russian ruble or Soviet ruble]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - European - Misc> ~27719~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: Purpose-built facilities for this activity often have features named for the Hubba Hideout in San Francisco. 92-year-old master planner Edmund Bacon engaged in this activity to protest Mayor John Street’s crackdown on this activity in Philadelphia’s LOVE Park. Alvar Aalto’s design for kidney-shaped pools inadvertently provided for the (*) “vert” form of this activity in Southern California. People engage in this activity at the converted Church of Saint Barbara in Oviedo, Spain thanks to extensions for wall riding. A Marc Vallée photobook documents obstacles placed on rails to discourage grinding in this activity. For 10 points, name this activity, whose namesake “parks” let participants practice their kickflips.
tossups.answer: skateboarding [prompt on skating or extreme sports; reject “roller skating” or “rollerblading” or “inline skating”]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Geography - United States> ~28117~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: In this city, a woman who is called “a veritable peace-maker” loses her plumcake on a train and repeats the first verse of a song twice. A boy in this city thinks about the words “gnomon,” “simony,” and “paralysis” before overhearing his aunt discussing the death of Father Flynn. A man watches the “snow falling faintly” in this city after (*) Kate and Julia’s party. In this setting of “Clay” and “The Sisters,” a boy promises Mangan’s sister a gift from the title bazaar, but finds that it is already closed. In this city, Gretta reminisces about Michael Furey, upsetting Gabriel Conroy. This city is the setting of “Araby” and “The Dead.” For 10 points, name this city, whose inhabitants are the namesake of a collection of stories by James Joyce.
tossups.answer: Dublin [accept Dubliners]
tossups.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Short Fiction> ~28562~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: Despite hearing news about this event, officials at Clark Field failed to swiftly implement the Rainbow 5 plan. The first Roberts Commission investigated this event. A few days before this event, Cordell Hull delivered a note embargoing oil exports. This event led to the demotion of Husband Kimmel. A participant in this event was controversially given good treatment after crashing on (*) Niihau. For heroics during this event, Doris Miller became the first Black man to earn a Navy Cross. Rear Admiral Isaac C. Kidd and 1,176 other crewmen were killed on a ship that now serves as a memorial of this event. For 10 points, the USS Arizona was sunk during what surprise attack that brought the US into World War II?
tossups.answer: attack on Pearl Harbor [accept Operation AI or Operation Z; prompt on answers like the entry of the United States into World War II or the opening of the Pacific Theater; prompt on an attack on Hawaii or Hawaii operation]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - American - 1865-1945> ~27339~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

tossups.question: James Longacre created a design of this figure wearing a Native American headdress. A sculpture of this figure originated as a hooded peasant after its artist was stunned by the image of Nubian deities at Abu Simbel. This figure steps onto a rock in a design whose relief had to be lowered by Augustus Saint-Gaudens. Aztec pyramids partly inspired Richard Morris Hunt’s design for a (*) pedestal for a statue of this figure whose creation was encouraged by Édouard René de Laboulaye. This figure holds a Roman-style tablet and has broken shackles around her feet in an 1886 statue whose metal framework was completed by Gustave Eiffel. For 10 points, Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi designed a copper statue of what figure holding a torch over New York’s harbor?
tossups.answer: Liberty [or Libertas; accept the Statue of Liberty or Liberty Enlightening the World]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Sculpture> ~27318~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: In a poem titled for this location, the speaker describes how they “failed to love a tree in each person” to describe their disillusionment with modern life. A poem about this place uses the imagery of fingers “emerging from the jungle.” That poem about this place juxtaposes two concepts in each line beginning with “sidereal eagle, misty vine.” The speaker of one poem plunges their hands into the ground at this place and feels (*) long-forgotten heartbeats. While at this place, the speaker asks unseen people to “speak through my words and my blood” and “rise up in birth with me.” For 10 points, the second section of Pablo Neruda’s Canto General is titled for the “Heights” of what ancient city in Peru?
tossups.answer: Machu Picchu [accept “The Heights of Macchu Picchu” or “Las Alturas de Macchu Picchu”; prompt on the Andes or America]
tossups.metadata: Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~28505~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: Note to moderator: read the answerline carefully. Note to players: two answers required. People with these two traits are analogized to “silent witnesses” in a pioneering text of a movement centered on them, A Voice from the South. The “Thought” of a movement centered on people with these two traits titles a 1990 book describing them as the “outsider-within.” A UCLA scholar coined one concept in papers like “Mapping the Margins” to analyze employment discrimination against people with these two (*) identities. Patricia Hill Collins identified harmful “controlling images” that people with these two identities contend with, like the matriarch and welfare queen. Kimberlé Crenshaw coined intersectionality to analyze the layered discrimination faced by people with, for 10 points, what marginalized racial and gender identity?
tossups.answer: Black AND female [or Black AND woman; accept African-American for Black; accept girls or mothers for women; prompt on Black feminism or Black Feminist Thought; prompt on women of color or WOC; prompt on minority or non-white for “Black”]
tossups.metadata: Vincent Du, Social Science - Sociology> ~28104~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: A quantity describing this phenomenon is estimated iteratively via the reciprocal of its square root with the Colebrook–White equation. A quantity describing this phenomenon appears on the vertical axis of a log–log plot that features a steep line to the left of many nearly parallel decreasing curves to show when that “factor” of this phenomenon equals 64 over the Reynolds number. This phenomenon drives head loss, which is calculated in the (*) Darcy–Weisbach equation. A form of drag named for this phenomenon is driven by turbulence against objects’ “skin.” A pipe’s roughness contributes to this phenomenon, causing energy loss during fluid flow. For 10 points, name this force that is reduced by lubricants.
tossups.answer: friction [or friction force] (The first two sentences describe the Darcy friction factor. The plot in the second sentence is the Moody diagram.)
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~28614~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: One of these creatures is called “prosperous in proper sense” and is urged to “make miniature Valhalla of my heart” in a Gwendolyn Brooks poem titled for “A Light and Diplomatic” one. Another poem contrasts one of these creatures that “floats downstream till the current ends” with one that “stands on the grave of dreams.” In a poem, one of these creatures with “a pain” that “still throbs in the old, old scars” performs an action until “its blood is red on the (*) cruel bars.” One of these creatures makes “a plea that upward to Heaven he flings” in Paul Laurence Dunbar’s poem “Sympathy.” For 10 points, name these animals, one of which “sings of freedom” in a Maya Angelou poem titled for a “caged” one.
tossups.answer: birds [or caged bird; or free bird; or broken-winged bird; accept “A Light and Diplomatic Bird”; reject specific species of birds such as “nightingale”]
tossups.metadata: Tim Morrison, Literature - American - Poetry> ~13643~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: One side in this conflict rallied around a slogan that followed the name of a leader in this conflict with the phrase “or we burn the country.” Tensions in this conflict increased when the Air Force Intelligence Directorate dumped a mutilated body in the city of Daraa. This conflict began with a mass “Revolution of Dignity” against the Alawite-dominated ruling party. An American (*) president refused to further escalate this conflict after one side crossed a “red line” and perpetrated the Ghouta chemical attack. A photograph shows a two-year-old refugee from this conflict named Alan Kurdi who drowned when attempting to cross to Greece in 2015. For 10 points, name this ongoing conflict in a country mostly led by Bashar al-Assad.
tossups.answer: Syrian Civil War [accept Syrian Revolution; accept Revolution of Dignity until read]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~27424~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Robert Schumann quoted this piece in his song “The Two Grenadiers,” which is included in the second Suzuki method book. Hector Berlioz dedicated his grandiose 1830 orchestration of this piece to Claude-Joseph Rouget de Lisle (“roo-JAY de LEEL”). In an E-flat major work, the brass play this piece to contrast with the tambourine-accompanied folk song “At the Gate,” while its first instance interrupts the (*) Troparion of the Holy Cross. Lyrics in this song include “Against us the bloody flag of tyranny is raised.” This piece is drowned out by “God Save the Tsar” in the 1812 Overture, which uses this piece to represent Napoleon’s army. For 10 points, name or describe this revolutionary patriotic song from Berlioz’s home country.
tossups.answer: “La Marseillaise” (“mar-say-EZZ”) [or “The Marseillaise”; accept national anthem of France or French national anthem; prompt on national anthem] (Robert Schumann was born 214 years ago to the day of the NSC. Happy birthday, Robert!)
tossups.metadata: Jeffrey Liu, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~28087~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: L-glutamine powder was approved to treat this disease in 2017. bluebird bio’s lentiviral treatment for this disease was approved on the same day in November 2023 as the first-ever CRISPR gene therapy, which also treats this condition. For 50 years, the only available drug for this molecular disease was a derivative of urea that activates synthesis of an alpha-gamma tetramer normally made only by (*) infants. This disease can be treated by transplanting bone marrow without the glutamate-to-valine mutation in beta-globin. Sufferers of this disease experience excruciating vaso-occlusion crises when erythrocytes get stuck in capillaries. For 10 points, name this genetic disease common in Black Americans which deforms red blood cells.
tossups.answer: sickle cell disease [or sickle cell anemia; or sickle cell trait; or SCA or SCD or SCT; prompt on anemia]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~27633~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: In a Pushkin-popularized fairytale, every time Tsar Dadon hears this sound, he sends his armies off to war. A hanged pilgrim in the Portuguese city of Barcelos was deemed innocent after a roasted corpse produced this sound. Prior to hearing this sound and repenting, a Biblical man denies his Galilean heritage while sitting by a fire. In the Völuspá, Egdir’s harp is interrupted by Fjalarr and Gullinkambi as they emit this sound to herald (*) Ragnarok. This sound is lethal to a creature incubated by an egg-sitting toad, the “king of serpents.” This sound is lethal to cockatrices and basilisks. For 10 points, Jesus predicts that Peter will deny him thrice prior to hearing what sound, which more generally heralds the dawn?
tossups.answer: the crowing of a rooster [or a rooster noise; or cock-a-doodle-doo, or cocorocó or cocoricó, or kikiriku, or cocococo, or gaggalagó; accept synonyms for rooster like cock and male chicken; prompt on chicken; reject “hen”]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, RMP - World Mythology> ~27790~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: In the 1990s, researchers used DNA from corpses at Kerameikos to correlate a disease outbreak during this war to typhoid fever. A passage about this war inspired Graham T. Allison to coin the name of a “trap” often invoked in discussions of US-China relations. A speech that offered “comfort, not condolences,” to bereaved citizens during this war was given by a leader killed during a (*) plague outbreak. During this war’s Archidamian phase, one city was defended by the Long Walls. The argument that “the strong do what they can, and the weak suffer what they must” was invoked during one side’s siege of Melos during this war. Thucydides wrote a history of, for 10 points, what war between Athens and Sparta?
tossups.answer: Peloponnesian War [accept History of the Peloponnesian War]
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, History - European - Classical> ~28220~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: In January 2023, the Camp Blaz (“blahz”) Marine Corps base opened on this island. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this island also home to Andersen Air Force Base. Although people born on this westernmost US territory are citizens, they cannot vote in presidential elections while living here.

Over 40 percent of Chamoru families on Guam are on food stamps, in part due to high grocery prices caused by this legislation. This legislation requires that US-flagged ships and crew transport goods between US ports.
Guam likely will be devastated by DF-26 missiles if China launches an invasion of this other island. DPP candidate Lai Ching-te won a 2024 presidential election here.
answers: Taiwan [prompt on Republic of China or ROC or Zhōnghuá Mínguó]

bonuses.leadin: In a play by this author, Annette throws up on a coffee table during a meeting between the parents of Ferdinand and Bruno, who had a fight in the park. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French author of God of Carnage. Serge purchases an all-white painting on which his friend doodles a skier in this author’s play Art.
Reza is a four-time winner of a French drama award named for this playwright of Tartuffe and The Misanthrope.

In Art, Serge has this job, which Sganarelle (“zgan-ah-REL”) is forced into “in spite of himself” in a Moliere play. Molière ironically died while playing the character Argan, who will only let his daughter marry a man with this job.
answers: doctor [accept dermatologist; accept The Doctor In Spite of Himself or Le Medecin Malgre Lui]
bonuses.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Drama> ~22677~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

bonuses.leadin: A painting titled for this figure was exhibited alongside a poem that calls the artist’s wife Gala “my [this figure].” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this figure who titles a painting that depicts a backward statue standing on top of a chessboard. In that painting, this figure’s hand springs out of the ground to hold a cracked egg.

This Japanese artist handed out metal balls at the Venice Biennale (“bee-en-NAH-lay”) for her performance piece Narcissus Garden. She is best known for her Instagram-friendly Infinity Mirror Rooms and her frequent use of polka dots.
An artist with this surname created a drawing of Narcissus clasping his face in his hands. That artist with this surname was the grandson of the author of The Interpretation of Dreams.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~22198~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: Devices that measure this quantity are often used in seismographs, so their proof mass is sometimes called “seismic mass.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity, the rate of change of velocity.
Aircraft accelerometers are included in navigation systems named for this adjective. This adjective describes non-accelerating reference frames.

In a MEMS accelerometer, displacement of the seismic mass yields a measurable change in this electromagnetic quantity, which scales with one over separation distance. Positioning systems that detect displacement via this quantity are contrasted with ones that detect eddy currents.
answers: capacitance [or nominal capacitance; prompt on C] (Capacitive displacement sensors rely on an electric field, while eddy current displacement sensors rely on a magnetic field.)
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Physics> ~23910~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: At this civilization’s trading post of Shortugai, archaeologists found carnelian beads that resembled those made at Dholavira. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this civilization which scholars associate with the Sumerian trading partner Meluhha. A bronze sculpture produced by this civilization depicts a performer wearing bangles.
Shortugai was situated near mines of this semi-precious blue stone, once thought to be used in Babylon’s Ishtar Gate.

Some scholars have argued that the Harappans spoke a precursor to this language family based on similarities between “Meluhha” and a word for sesame. Rulers of the Chola Empire spoke a language from this family.
answers: Indus Valley Civilization [or IVC; or Harappan Civilization] (The sculpture is Dancing Girl.)
Dravidian languages [accept Proto-Dravidian; reject “Tamil”] (The language is Tamil.)
bonuses.metadata: Hari Parameswaran, History - World - Asian> ~23893~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following questions about the pair of IPA consonants represented by theta and eth (“EH-th”), which are both typically spelled as “th” in English, for 10 points each.
parts: Theta and eth are sounds made with the tip of the tongue touching these body parts, since they have an interdental place of articulation.
Theta and eth are distinct because eth has this characteristic, in which producing the sound causes the larynx to vibrate. Similarly, “b” (“BUH”) has this characteristic, but “p” (“PUH”) does not.
The difference between theta and eth is demonstrated by the words “thy” and “thigh,” an example of one of these pairs of words that differ only in a single phoneme.
bonuses.metadata: Abhinav Rachakonda, Social Science - Linguistics> ~22965~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: A 1978 book by Peter Matthiessen chronicles a months-long search for one of these animals. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these animals. In the opening of a short story, the frozen carcass of one of these animals is mysteriously located at a place the Maasai called the “House of God.”
In The Snow Leopard, Matthiessen is aided in his search by footprints on this mountain. In Jon Krakauer’s Into Thin Air, eight people die trying to summit this Himalayan mountain.
In this novel, Allie Cone experiences a hallucinatory vision upon scaling Everest. She dies later in this novel after Farishta pushes her off the Everest Vilas apartment complex.
answers: leopards [accept snow leopards; accept African leopards or Panthera pardus pardus; accept Panthera uncia] (The mentioned short story is “The Snows of Kilimanjaro.”)
bonuses.metadata: Jeffrey Liu, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~23612~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: This chord progression begins with a perfect cadence, followed by the sequence [read slowly] “flat seven - flat three - flat seven - minor one.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Iberian chord progression that Arcangelo Corelli used as the basis for the 12th and last of his Opus 5 violin sonatas.

“La Folia” was often used as the basis for these slow, triple meter Spanish dances. This dance was typically the third movement of Baroque dance suites, coming after the allemande and courante and before the gigue.
The sarabande from this composer’s fourth suite for harpsichord uses a chord progression based on La Folia. This composer also wrote the oratorio Messiah.
bonuses.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~22757~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: This Supreme Court justice was the first to be called to testify at their own confirmation hearing. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this justice who wrote the majority opinion in the Minersville case. He was appointed to the “Jewish seat” previously held by Benjamin Cardozo and Louis Brandeis.
Two answers required. Frankfurter was painted as a Communist because he defended these two men who were executed for supposedly robbing a store in Braintree.
The Minersville case ruled that schools could compel students to salute the flag and perform this action. In 1954, the words “under God” were added to text used for this action.
answers: Sacco AND Vanzetti [accept Nicola Sacco AND Bartolomeo Vanzetti in either order; prompt on partial answers]
reciting the Pledge of Allegiance [or answers relating to pledging allegiance to the flag of the United States]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - American - 1865-1945> ~22162~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

bonuses.leadin: al-Tabari relates that Muhammad had a sakinah resembling the white face of one of these animals placed within his heart. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these animals. After one of them belonging to Abu Hurairah pounced on a snake, Muhammad scratched its back and gave all these animals the ability to land on their feet.

Note to moderator: read answerline carefully. In one hadith, Muhammad relates how a woman was condemned to this place for starving a cat. People who fall off a bridge called Sirat end up in this Islamic hell.

Moulana Ashraf Ali Thanvi narrated a story of how a man saw a cat’s face while staring at a saint of this tradition, whose graves are pilgrimage sites called dargahs. This tradition includes the Mevlevi Order.
answers: cats [or felines; accept specific types of cats such as tabby cats; accept qita or qitat]
Sufism [or Sufis or taSawwuf or as-sufiyya; prompt on dervishes or whirling dervishes]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, RMP - Islam> ~22480~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: Unlike most other thermodynamic state functions, this quantity is defined to be zero at absolute zero. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this measure of a system’s disorder.

The other state functions are defined to be zero at this temperature, the thermodynamic standard state. Please give your answer rounded to the nearest integer in kelvins or degrees Celsius, but do not give the temperature of STP, which is lower.

The entropy at other pressures is calculated by integrating the coefficient of this process times volume. Lord Kelvin first measured absolute zero by realizing the coefficient of this process is one over temperature for an ideal gas.
answers: 298 Kelvin [or 25 degrees Celsius; accept 298.15 Kelvin or 298.2 Kelvin; reject “STP” or “0” or “273”]
thermal expansion [or thermal expansion coefficient or coefficient of thermal expansion; prompt on expansion; prompt on heating or cooling]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~22774~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: Sierra Leone’s Poro healers confiscate examples of these objects made from brown sugar to stop witches from spreading disease. For 10 points each:
parts: The devil gifts what magical objects in Carl Maria von Weber’s (“VAY-bur’s”) opera Der Freischütz (“dehr FRY-shoots”)? The Beast of Gévaudan (“zheh-voo-DAWN”) was slain by these objects derived from a melted chalice.
Soko Bana healers use razors to cut this body part to strengthen their powers. An ashamed deity wearing a mundamala reveals this body part as she steps on Shiva’s chest.
Other Poro society members don straw to mimic the Devil while performing this action. A stick is secured to the Gambian Kumpo’s head as they perform this action to the beat of drums.
answers: bullets [accept magic bullets or silver bullets; prompt on guns or rifles or pistols]
tongue [prompt on mouth; prompt on face] (The unnamed goddess is Kali.)
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, RMP - World Mythology> ~23647~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: Sir John is arrested for drunkenness while wearing a frock in a play titled for a “Provoked [one of these people]” by John Vanbrugh. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these people, one of whom titles a Restoration comedy by William Wycherly in which Horner uses multiple double entendres while describing his china collection.
In another play, the “Merry Wives of Windsor” created by this author prank his recurring character Falstaff.

An author with this first name and the last name Southerne wrote The Wives’ Excuse. A different author with this first name is the subject of Robert Bolt’s play A Man for All Seasons and described an island with no property.
answers: wife [or wives; accept The Provoked Wife or The Country Wife; prompt on women or spouses]
Thomas [accept Thomas Southerne or Sir Thomas More] (The island is Utopia.)
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - British - Drama> ~22931~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Queer Palm prize, which is awarded to films that deal with LGBTQ+ issues and themes, for 10 points each.
parts: The Queer Palm is awarded every year at this French film festival which also awards the Palme d’Or.

Near the end of this 2019 Queer Palm winner, the protagonist sees a former love interest at a performance of Vivaldi’s “Summer.” In this film, a woman commissioned to paint an aristocrat falls in love with her over the course of a week on a remote island in Brittany.
A director from this country was nominated for the Queer Palm in 2016 for his film The Handmaiden. A film from this country was the first non–English language film to win the Oscar for Best Picture.
answers: Portrait of a Lady on Fire [or Portrait de la jeune fille en feu] (Directed by Céline Sciamma.)
South Korea [or Republic of Korea; prompt on Korea] (The Handmaiden is by Park Chan-Wook. The unnamed film is Parasite by Bong Joon-ho.)
bonuses.metadata: Wonyoung Jang, Fine Arts - Film> ~22900~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: In 1923, a Harlem newspaper alleged a cover-up about this man’s skin color. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who owned an iron dagger made from a meteorite. A blockbuster exhibit on the “treasures” of this ruler at the Met in the 1970s benefited the Philae temple complex.

This man signed an exclusive newspaper contract to print Harry Barton’s King Tut photos. When this financial backer of the expedition asked, “Can you see anything?”, Howard Carter answered, “Yes, wonderful things!”
The world tour of Tut’s treasures in the 1970s was made possible by an indemnity act signed into law by this president, who succeeded fellow Republican Richard Nixon.
answers: Lord Carnarvon [or George Edward Stanhope Molyneux Herbert, 5th Earl of Carnarvon; or Lord Porchester]
Gerald Ford [or Gerald Rudolph Ford Jr.; or Leslie Lynch King Jr.]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~22179~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: The CfA’s LEDA (“LEE-duh”) experiment detects the 21-centimeter lines of photons emitted from this cosmological period. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this period preceded by recombination, in which the universe was transparent, but the only sources of photons were photon decoupling and hydrogen’s spin-flip transition.
LEDA detects 21-centimeter lines at values of 15-to-30 for this quantity, denoted z. This quantity measures the increase of wavelengths towards a namesake color.
The dark ages were followed by this period characterized by the gravitational stripping of electrons from neutral hydrogen. The earliest stars and black holes formed during this period.
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Science - Astronomy> ~23877~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: An early play from this conflict focused on a fictionalized trial for the traitor John André. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this conflict, the setting of plays by William Dunlap and Mercy Otis Warren, as well as the musical 1776.
In this play by Royall Tyler, the foppish British sycophant Mr. Dimple and the patriotic Colonel Manly compete for the hand of Maria Van Rough. This 1787 play is the earliest comedy from the US.
Comedy in The Contrast was inspired by the plays of this non-American author, one of which is performed in The Contrast itself. “Malapropisms” originate from this author’s play The Rivals.
answers: American Revolution [or the American Revolutionary War; or the American War of Independence]
bonuses.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, Literature - American - Drama> ~22905~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: A philosopher with this surname addressed the “gravest problem” of grounding normative principles without “absolutism” in an essay defending cultural pluralism. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this surname of the “Dean of the Harlem Renaissance.” An earlier philosopher with this surname argued against Catholic persecution in A Letter Concerning Toleration.

Alain Locke argues for a pluralism of these concepts in an essay titled “[these concepts] and Imperatives.” Axiology is the study of these concepts, which are contrasted with “facts” in a dichotomy related to the is-ought problem.
Alain Locke’s value theory also responds to the value “anarchism” of this psychologist who wrote Pragmatism.
answers: values [accept value theory or “Values and Imperatives” or fact–value dichotomy or fact–value distinction]
bonuses.metadata: Jordan Brownstein, RMP - Philosophy> ~22159~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: Bohemond of Taranto led a Crusader state based in this city. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ancient Syrian city in modern-day Turkey between Edessa and Tripoli. This city was named for the father of Seleucus Nicator.

The similarly named Antioch of Pisidia was home to Margaret the Virgin, who was praised in this work. Personifications of Reason, Justice, and Rectitude invite Christine de Pizan to build the title place of this work.
Because vinegar failed to preserve his body, this king was buried in Antioch after he drowned in the Saleph River. This Holy Roman Emperor who feuded with the Lombards was named for his red beard.
answers: Antioch [or Antiochus; or Antakya; reject “Antioch of Pisidia” or “Antioch in Pisidia”]
The Book of the City of Ladies [or Le Livre de la Cité des Dames]
Frederick Barbarossa [or Frederick I or Friedrich I or Federico I; prompt on Frederick or Friedrich or Federico; prompt on Barbarossa]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - European - Middle Ages> ~22175~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: In 1888, Leo Errera theorized that cells in this kingdom divide like a soap bubble, minimizing the surface area of the cell plate to form the shortest symmetric path. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this kingdom of eukaryotes that have cell walls made of cellulose.
The soap bubble theory fails in the “apical” type of this undifferentiated plant tissue, since cells in it divide longitudinally to grow the tips of the shoots or roots.

By contrast, animal cells usually divide down their longest axis due to the activity of this family of motor proteins. These proteins move cargo down microtubules toward the nucleus, in the opposite direction as kinesins (“kye-NEE-sins”).
answers: meristem [accept apical meristem or root apical meristem or stem apical meristem; reject “lateral meristem”or “cambium”]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~23326~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: This author supposedly used the gleam of his cat’s eyes to write at night, since he couldn’t afford candles. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Italian author, best known for an epic poem in which the warrior-maiden Clorinda dramatically converts to Christianity after being fatally injured during a night battle at the title city’s gates.
Clorinda appears in a Tasso epic titled for “[this city] Delivered.” A William Blake poem titled for this Holy City opens, “And did those feet in ancient time / Walk upon England’s mountains green.”
This author of “The Sorcerer’s Apprentice” and Elective Affinities wrote most of his play Torquato Tasso while journeying to Italy in the 1780s.
answers: Jerusalem [accept Jerusalem Delivered or The Liberation of Jerusalem or La Gerusalemme Liberata]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - European - Poetry> ~23812~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson
